description: Indicates the number of transaction requests that returned this HTTP response code during the last measurement period.
interpretation: Compare across HTTP response codes to know if error transactions exceed successful ones. High errors imply sub-par user experience. Use detailed diagnosis to identify affected transactions.
troubleshootingSteps: Compare the volume of successful (2xx) vs. error (4xx/5xx) requests to determine the severity of the issue.[web:517][web:523]
If the total request count is unexpectedly low or zero, check for network connectivity issues, DNS failures, or a down server process.[web:512][web:519]
If the total count is abnormally high (spike), investigate potential DDoS attacks, bot traffic, or a misconfigured client retrying requests aggressively.[web:516][web:519]

description: Indicates the number of transaction requests that returned this HTTP response per minute.
interpretation: Compare across HTTP response codes. Frequent error responses are a cause for concern.
troubleshootingSteps: Correlate spikes in 'requests per minute' with server resource usage (CPU/Memory) to see if high load is causing errors (e.g., 503 Service Unavailable).[web:513][web:522]
Set alerts for sudden drops or spikes in traffic to detect outages or surges early.[web:517][web:522]

description: Indicates the number of transaction requests with this HTTP response, which were redirected to error pages during the last measurement period.
interpretation: Ideally, the value of this measure should be low.
troubleshootingSteps: High redirection counts often indicate broken links or changed URL structures; review 404 logs to fix internal broken links or set up proper 301 redirects.[web:521][web:524]
Ensure that the custom error page itself is not throwing an error (e.g., infinite redirect loop), which would compound the issue.[web:521][web:524]

description: Indicates the percentage of transactions requests that returned HTTP response codes of the range 200-299.
interpretation: Represents successful responses. A high value is desired.

description: Indicates the percentage of transactions requests that returned HTTP response codes of the range 300-399.
interpretation: Represents redirection responses. Ideally, the value should be low.
troubleshootingSteps: If 3xx percentage is high, check for redirect loops or excessive chaining (e.g., A -> B -> C), which slows down the user experience and impacts SEO.[web:518][web:521]
Update client applications or internal links to point directly to the new destination URL instead of relying on the redirect.[web:518][web:521]

description: Indicates the percentage of transactions requests that returned HTTP response codes of the range 400-499.
interpretation: Represents client errors (bad syntax, not found). Ideally, the value should be low.
troubleshootingSteps: Analyze 4xx logs to distinguish between 404 (Not Found) and 401/403 (Unauthorized/Forbidden); fix broken links for 404s and check permission settings for 403s.[web:516][web:517][web:525]
If seeing high 429 (Too Many Requests), check if a specific client is being rate-limited and whether the rate limits are configured correctly.[web:519]
Review client-side code to ensure it is constructing valid requests (correct method, headers, payload) to avoid 400 Bad Request errors.[web:516][web:519]

description: Indicates the percentage of transactions requests that returned HTTP response codes of the range 500-599.
interpretation: Represents server errors (failed to fulfill valid request). Ideally, the value should be low.
troubleshootingSteps: Treat 5xx errors as critical server-side failures. Check server application logs (Java, PHP, Node.js, etc.) for exceptions or stack traces corresponding to the 500 timestamp.[web:517][web:520][web:525]
For 502/504 errors (Bad Gateway / Gateway Timeout), investigate the backend service or database; it may be down, overloaded, or timing out.[web:517][web:519][web:520]
Ensure server capacity (CPU/RAM) is sufficient to handle the load; scale up resources if 503 errors (Service Unavailable) occur during traffic peaks.[web:513][web:522]
